Can Planting Billions Of Trees Halt Climate Change?

text: Reducing Greenhouse Gas Emissions Can Improve Air Quality and Save Lives. Reducing global greenhouse gas emissions to slow climate change could prevent millions of premature deaths due to air pollution over the next century, according a new study funded by NIEHS.
author: Ranty M

text: Greenhouse gases have far-ranging environmental and health effects. They cause climate change by trapping heat, and they also contribute to respiratory disease from smog and air pollution. Extreme weather, food supply disruptions, and increased wildfires are other effects of climate change caused by greenhouse gases
author: Ranty M

text:
How do greenhouse gases affect the economy?

A 2017 study found that in China, 1.23 million air pollution-related deaths in 2010 represented up to 13.2% of the country‚Äôs GDP. In the same year, air pollution caused over 23 000 deaths in the UK, representing up to 7.1% of the GDP. Another report projects that annual premature deaths due to outdoor air pollution will increase to up to 9 million people in 2060 from 3 million in 2010, as well as an increase in annual global hospital admissions: 11 million people in 2060 from 3.6 million people in 2010. Reducing carbon emissions would decrease the number of deaths related to air pollution and help to ease pressure on healthcare systems.
author: Ranty M

text: The climate crisis is the most pressing issue humanity is facing today; global temperatures have increased by 1C since the pre-industrial period and under current policies, are expected to increase by 3.1-3.7C by the end of the century. Compounding the problem is that carbon emissions remain in the atmosphere for 100 years and up to 80% of this dissolves into the ocean over a period of 20- 200 years. The crisis not only has impacts for the environment, but also for the economy. Evidence shows that reducing carbon emissions will benefit the economy, but will governments make the decisive actions needed?
author: Ranty M

text: Reducing carbon emissions would decrease the number of deaths related to air pollution and help to ease pressure on healthcare systems. To achieve growth in the economy while still prioritising the reduction of carbon emissions, a decoupling between the two is needed.
author: Ranty M

text: Estimates of how much money it would take to end global climate change range between $300 billion and $50 trillion over the next two decades.

text: If you got past the 6th grade you probably learned about plant photosynthesis.  Plants need sunlight, water and CO2 to grow.  All life on this planet is carbon based.  CO2 is the primary source of carbon for life.  CO2 is essential for life.  If CO2 levels fall below 150 ppm (parts per million), plants cannot survive.  If plants cannot survive, animals and humans will struggle to survive.  For most of earth's 4.7 billion year history, CO2 levels have been dramatically higher than today.  Most modern plants evolved during periods when CO2 was 3 to 5 times higher, and consider the current climate to be in a CO2 drought.  Plants have pores they open to absorb CO2, in our low CO2 climate they need to open them often more of to absorb sufficient CO2.  Every time they open, vapor escapes... as a result plants are far more water efficient in higher levels of CO2, and less water efficient in lower CO2.  Plants are more drought resilient in higher levels of CO2.   Corn, wheat, rice and other course grain yields have increased 300% over the last 60 years do to the little bit of extra CO2 in the atmosphere.  India is now a net exporter of wheat, they cannot eat all the wheat the produce.  When you drive in your car you are experiencing significantly higher levels of CO2 than exist in the atmosphere.  Each human emits about 800 pounds of CO2 into the atmosphere each year simply by breathing.  We exhale about 100 times the amount of CO2 we absorbed when inhaling.  Mother Nature emits significantly more CO2 than humans do by burning fossil fuels.  The oceans, which cover 70% of the earth continually emit it from vast deposits of naturally dissolved CO2, natural fires, volcanoes and decaying plant life continually emit it... and of course breathing animals including humans emit it.  Life thrives near the warm equator and struggles near the cold poles.  During the Cambrian period (the Cambrian Explosion) when an explosion of life burst onto the earth 500 million years ago it was significantly warmer and CO2 levels were 5 times what they are today.  CO2 is essential for life.  Pick up a science book some time.
author: Jim R

text: The IPCC states what has actually been observed over the last 170 years is about 1C of warming and 340mm of sea level rise (13.4 inches), which is neither catastrophic or extreme.  The claims of future catastrophic change are nothing more than speculation based on models that have failed miserably at predicting climate.  It was warmer 1000, 2000 and 7000 years ago than today, while CO2 levels were significantly lower and all during periods well before humans began burning fossil fuels.  From about 12000 years ago to about 7000 years ago the earth warmed dramatically coming out of the most recent glaciation period... sea levels rose about 400 feet over that time.  This was an immense period of natural warming and sea level increase all while CO2 remained relatively low.  How can one explain this without acknowledging that CO2 cannot be the primary driver of the earth's complex and chaotic climate.

text:
¬†@Appable¬† - Thanks for looking. The first part, the steadily increasing fee charged to fossil fuel producers based on the climate pollution from the products they sell, fixes the failure of the energy market to account for the costs of the pollution from using fossil fuels.  It enables efficient market forces to reduce climate pollution effectively and at the least-cost according to most economists (http://clcouncil.org/economists-statement). 
The second part is what to do with the money collected.  This policy rebates all the money collected back to all households on an equal basis each month as a dividend. This recoups us all for the damages from the pollution. It also has a very progressive effect: two-thirds of all households break even or receive more in their monthly dividend than they pay in higher prices due to the fee.  Those who come out ahead are those with smaller than average carbon footprints, which includes most low-income households. 
The benefits can be seen in the four-page summary of a report by REMI, available here: http://citizensclimatelobby.org/remi-report

text:
Go vegan. 

The study, published in the journal Science, created a huge dataset based on almost 40,000 farms in 119 countries and covering 40 food products that represent 90% of all that is eaten. It assessed the full impact of these foods, from farm to fork, on land use, climate change emissions, freshwater use and water pollution (eutrophication) and air pollution (acidification).

‚ÄúA vegan diet is probably the single biggest way to reduce your impact on planet Earth, not just greenhouse gases, but global acidification, eutrophication, land use and water use,‚Äù said Joseph Poore, at the University of Oxford, UK, who led the research. ‚ÄúIt is far bigger than cutting down on your flights or buying an electric car,‚Äù he said, as these only cut greenhouse gas emissions.

text:
Once upon a time there were several types of human species that roamed the earth. We have lost that ‚Äúbiodiversity‚Äù and have killed them all. Our species does nothing for the environment. We humans are the ultimate consumers / parasites. We build roads and buildings to live in and make more people that do the same with increasing speed and efficiency.The only way to help is for the human race to end or just hit pause for the next 20 years. 

You say plant trees provided they are native to an area. I get it but here‚Äôs something to think about.. When you choose those native trees to plant, did you use ‚Äúnative soil‚Äù? And why choose THOSE native trees instead of ALL the others. The process is completely ARTIFICIAL and you are still tinkering with nature. Humans don‚Äôt get it. There is no such thing as ‚Äúwildlife management‚Äù. Either it is wildlife is truly Wild and free - not interfered with by humans or people are imposing their will upon them. There is nothing natural about it. It‚Äôs all humans playing around with what we think the world should look like. It doesn‚Äôt matter if you plant a native plant, a flower from another state, or a vegetable garden - it‚Äôs a human form of control defined by humans.

Imagine if some superior being lived on earth that was higher up on the food chain than us and felt we should only live in our native range. Everyone outside of Africa would be exterminated or moved back to Africa where humans are from. And then imagine if that being ‚Äúmanaged us‚Äù to where we could only eat plants and animals from out native range and said it was to preserve us and our species. It‚Äôs funny how humans can act elitist imposing their will on what they think should exist in an ecosystem with their imagination of what is ‚Äúnative‚Äù while calling for biodiversity (essentially ‚Äúegg is more than one basket‚Äù  to allow families of organisms to continue even when faced with stressors that eliminate part of their species) and yet humans are walking contradictions. Everything we have done to flourish as a species has benefited from our ability to gather resources from all parts of the earth. 

The best thing to do for nature is to get out of it‚Äôs way and let it do what it wants to ‚Äúunmanaged‚Äù. Unfortunately, humans are not going to stop making humans. They will not stop big industry. And, they wil not stop trying to MANAGE ‚Äúnature‚Äù by imposing our view of how it should work. The more people dip their hands into nature the less nature we have. Even those that are planting native plants. That‚Äôs not nature. That‚Äôs humans growing another type of crop. 

Think about it.

author: Jukes Food

text:
¬†@Dale Crocker¬† Planting trees is a normally good idea but for different reasons. The type of tree, and where you plant them is very important. Planting fast-growing trees like gum trees and pines is not generally a good idea. Firstly trees like gum trees are highly combustible because of the oils they contain. The life cycle of gum forests relies on fire to regenerate itself. So for carbon storage, not a good idea.
 Pine/conifers forests tend to leave the soil deficient. Things that grow fast usually have a shorter life span so this means carbon collected will return sooner. All trees lose leaves but deciduous tree loses theirs in Autumn which is why the CO2 levels increase because the trees/leaves are not absorbing CO2 and the leaves decomposing on the ground return CO2 back to the atmosphere. 

Going half-cocked and planting millions of trees willy nilly without planning you know will come back to bite in the future. Nature has a way of establishing land which is smaller plant establishers first, followed by larger shrub/tree species and then more long term trees. Native plantings are possibly the safest bet, but I like the idea of fruit/nut/ olive orchards that way it is a win-win. 

All living things respire so plants produce CO2 all the time but more at night. Basically, all glucose/staches/fats are carbon compounds so when the animal/plant needs some energy for growth/metabolism it burns the glucose which releases CO2 in the process. 

Shells/rocks are a better store of carbon but will release CO2 under weathering.
Just to add for Juke

Because carbon via CO2  is such a useful builder for life there is a comparative lack of it in the atmosphere true. There is a point however where too much is not as good, so the idea of CO2 as plant food is only partly true as there are many things that plants need to grow successfully.  Optimum levels for most plants seems to be around 800ppmto 1200ppm. Beyond these levels, it can then start effecting uptake of nitrogen which is used in building protein content in crops.
C4 and Cam plants there are fewer advantages to increased CO2. 90% of plants are C3 plants and get most of the benefits from increased CO2 levels to a point.

As someone that works with data and advises on the importance of data integrity, the data for ground temperature trends is useless.  To have data collection retain its integrity in this instance, variables need to be controlled. When a ground measuring station used to be in a meadow, and now resides in a parking lot then guess what, it will read hire temperatures ... duh.  But this is part of the data collection.  Don‚Äôt trust me, go and do the research yourself on data collection for weather.  Most of the data that is accurate is only from the late 70s.  40 yrs of data when looking at 20,000-40,000 yrs between earth heating cooling tells you nothing.  I am fully for reducing our pollution, but from data, it is clear we are not the cause of any perceived global changes.  Remove humans from the equation and weather trends would remain the same.  Let‚Äôs not forget, dinosaurs used to live in Alberta, Canada, now a rich fossil and oil deposited area.  Temps there had to be mid 30¬∞C year round, the earth will do what it‚Äôs always done. text:
CO2 is plant food.
Where a commercial greenhouse is maintained around 1200 ppm of CO2, our atmosphere is at 415ppm.
The earth is starved of carbon.
With fossil fuels the crbon emitted has worked its way into the soils.
Scientists confirm the earth has greened by 40% over the last 30 years.
Along with added Carbon comes greater diversity of plant life, faster and greater crop yields.
Over the last two hundred million years the earth has had lower CO2 over 90% of that time frame.
So, plant trees and then reduce its natural fuel source, is nature that stupid in questioning how nature works.
The only question is, does higher CO2cequate to climate change.
Certainly nature happens.
Roy Spencer, a Nasa scientist was put in charge of a planned experiment, using satellite data, to prove the Greenhouse effect.
The results proved the effect was minimal and he openly said so.
So, the criticized and ignored him.
Radiation within our atmosphere has increased by 50%, since 2016; 
If this unquestioned jump did not result from CO2 then what caused it?
The Sun.
Valentina Zharkova, a mathematician Astrophysicist used Nasa data to create a predictive algorithm that has been accurate, 97% of the time over the last ten years in predicting changes within our sun.
6-7 years ago she predicted sunspots would reduce dramatically in numbers.
In 2019, there were no sunspots for almost 240 days.
Our sun, although stable enough does cyclically vary in its dynamic output, light and heat.
Zharkova found three circulating areas of plasma within the sun act like a motor to generate output.
Because these fields are always interacting, sometimes they inhibit and at other times reinforce their production.
Three phase is an example of wave amplitude.
Our sun has moved into its lowest point of magnetic field strength in hundreds of years.
A reduced magnetic field weakens the magnetosphere, which naturally protextscearth from excessive Solar and Cosmic radiation.
That is likely where the radiation is originating, not the Greenhouse effect.
As the air, land water warms, CO2 and Greenhouse gases are naturally forced from dissolved suspension, a symptom of warming.
Glacial ice samples show this.
Another interesting study helps to explain increased volcanic activity.
Study
Japanese researchers studied eruptions from four volcanoes over a 306 year period.
With almost complete certainty they said 9 of the 11 eruptions occured duringvlow points of magnetic field strength on our sun.
In other words the last time this occured, we had the same concerns.
The researchers postulated that UV within the radiation is heating and stimulating Muons within the lava rich lava..
Mike Morales confirms that same information.
Before we sign up to fight mother nature, we need open and honest dialogue with all scientists, not just the side they want heard.
Alternate thought is being purposely muzzled and that is not Science.
Greta, go sit down.

text:
Commercial greenhouses are maintained around 1200 ppm, while our atmosphere is 1/3 that.
As fossil fuels burn the carbon emitted works its way into the soil.
Greater CO2 means more diversity, faster growth and higher production.
Our earth has greened 40% in the last 30 years.
Nature reacts to increasing CO2 by growing more 4plant life to consume it.
Over the last 200 million years, only 20 million have had lower CO2.
The diversity of fauna increases with higher temps and CO2.
Look at tropical areas...
As CO2 is lowered this cycle is reversed.
Removing carbon is slapping nature in the face.
War with nature that never works out well.
Clean up, alternate fuels, recycle programs..fine.
Define the climate emergency, help the earth, do not attack it.
Many cite to examples of geoengineering already being utilized.
Filling our skies with particulate to block the suns effect.
High energy technologies such as HAARP, ionizing our atmosphere.
Notice how Global warming has become climate change?
Do not assume those who now ravage our planet mean well.
Question with an open mind.

text:
Disagreeing with you doesn't make someone a "weirdo" or a "conspiracy theorist." What a colossally arrogant thing to suggest.
The climate has been changing on this planet for the past 4.6 billion years. Why do you somehow think you're going to make it stop today by planting a tree, or even a million trees? You're delusional to think that. I'm all for environmental stewardship but this whole tree planting fad is nothing but pure virtue signalling from people who've allowed themselves to be convinced that they can play God and will the Earth to stop turning. Plant a tree if you want. Or don't. But at least have the good sense to plant trees which are appropriate adapted to your local climate and are not invasive species that are going to cause real problems long terms. We certainly have plenty of examples of naive morons throughout history who've released things into a local environment with no thought whatsoever for the actual change it will cause in the local ecosystem.


This whole logic of "any step is worth it" is nonsense. There are always pros and cons that have to be weighed to make a decision. There's always a cost that has to be paid, no matter what some politician or salesmen tells you is "free."

Sure, plant trees, but more CO2 will green the earth naturally.
Plant trees, then remove their natural food source?
Carbon in the atmosphere filters into the soil.
Trees are then bigger, more diverse, mature quicker and provide more yield.
As CO2 increases, so does that consuming it.
As CO2 drops this cycle is reversed.

text:
CO2 has been a legal pollutant in the US for over a decade, & a major occupational health & safety risk around the world. Over 4000 people a day, & 4.2 million people a year die due to air pollution. 
Too much CO2 causes vegetation "nutrient lockout" killing plants, as well as polluting soil & waterways causing aquatic "dead zones".
The cruellest & most shocking part of global warming is the liability of the economic cost, every country is vulnerable. Regional areas get hit first due to extreme drought, fires, & floods, & land becomes too expensive to insure. Agricultural areas starve and turn into obsolete ghost towns. 

USA are the largest polluters per capita, & the 2nd largest polluting country in the world. (China & India joined the Kyoto Protocol, Paris Agreement, & have national carbon taxes, - the US is the only developed country in the world that has no international mediation plan.)
The reason the world is being turned to toast is because of a couple of mid-American farmers want a few extra sunny days & have a blissfully ignorant view of global warming without all the pain, suffering, and cost, & they are too closed minded & lazy to learn modern farming technology & practices.

Renewable energy is 1/3rd the economic cost of nuclear power. Nuclear power price trends continue to get more expensive & the cost of renewables continues to drop. During heatwaves nuclear power plants need to be shut down to avoid melt down. After decommission the irradiated land of the power plant & waste storage areas need to be locked up indefinitely with expensive high security. Renewable energy uses less land & can be run cooperatively on existing used land.
A single nuclear power plant kills 32 million fish per year, & nuclear power causes more than 2000 times more bird strike than wind turbines. Nuclear power plants cause thermal heat & salt pollution killing water ways.

The highly land & economic efficient green chemistry, micro-algae natural carbon capture, & other new technologies & answers to solve the world's problems already exist but we are all too narrow minded and close minded to look!

American culture is very narcissistic & falsely thinks it represents the world.
In ten years one way or the other we will realise the mistake Conservatism and radical capitalism is.

Stay safe and good luck!
author: Peter Knagge

text: Trees are good in many cases for sure. BUT not all areas benefit from trees. Certain ecotypes are better based on temperature and rainfall. Areas that are historically grasslands for example are better as grasslands than forest. Grasses do store tons of carbon in their roots as they grow and die and regrow. Grasses are also better at preventing erosion in more arid regions since they provide a better coverage of the ground. I'm in West Texas which is currently over run by mesquite. Mesquite doesn't store carbon quite like the grasslands and leaves the ground bare in many places which increases erosion. Grasses can't compete with it as it shades out competition below it and has deeper roots allowing it to reach deeper water sources during dry periods preventing them from establishing. It's heavy establishment is likely because we removed fires from the grasslands a topic that is still being debated.

text:
Planting trees is not good if it destroys the natural ecosystems.  Tree planting is often a cynical, political and bureaucratic numbers game that ignores reality.  Take for example, Ireland, which regularly destroys immensely valuable wetlands in order to free up space for spruce tree plantations.  But biodiverse wetlands sequester way more carbon than monoculture tree plantations.
In effect, it's like razing rainforests to the ground, planting palm tree plantations in their stead, and acting like you're solving climate change.  
Nature plants trees for us, for free, without labor.  All we need to do it protect it.  The money spent on tree planting would be better spent protecting nature from further destruction.

text: You're actually wrong on a number of different fronts here. Increased temperature will evaporate more moisture from the oceans which will lead to there being more fresh water on the planet. Deserts are determined by geographical location, not global temperature. All deserts are centered¬†around 30 or 60deg latitude, it has to do with global air circulation patterns, ocean circulation and continental locations, nothing to do with temperature.Planting trees does not increase soil moisture as I have already explained in depth in this thread, you can go back and read about that. Or you can google it and learn from unbiased studies. To find unbiased studies I would suggest finding a study published before 2005, its not fool proof but its much less likely to be influenced by the global climate political agenda.
author: Mike D

text:
"Science has no agenda, political or otherwise"That is the most na√Øve thing I have ever heard. Pure science has no agenda, the scientists who carry out the majority of climate studies today do in fact have an agenda and got into the field because of the agenda.
"increased temperatures will in turn INCREASE the water level and decrease the salinity"¬† "the air will be able to HOLD/retain more water"
First we have to understand that all water comes from the ocean and is evaporated out of the ocean. Otherwise all the water flowing into the ocean via rivers would eventually drain all of the fresh water on earth and there would only be ocean. The ocean replenishes this moisture. If it is warmer more water will evaporate out of the ocean and cause more rain and more soil moisture. The salinity of the ocean should delight climate alarmists since they are afraid of the ocean acidification, a more saline ocean would combat the acidification since the salt is what raises the pH.From a scientific point of view the alarmists positions from issue to issue all¬†contradict each other. I was also indoctrinated in the alarmist point of view when I was in school. Then I started to wonder why each point of view is only explained individually and wondered why when you add them all together you get 10 different explanations that all contradict each other. Then I looked deeper and the "denier" point of view is consistent and scientifically valid from start to finish and none of the explanations contradict any of the others, the way science is supposed to work.

text: ¬†@Mike D¬† clearly you don‚Äôt understand how water works, water flows, most of it will eventually end up back in the ocean. If a place is getting less rainfall more and more of its waters will flow to the oceans and this there will be less fresh water. Planting trees helps preserve watery ecosystems by stopping erosion and encouraging transpiration which will rain back down in that area, keeping the water around in that environment longer, they also shade the ground allowing the soil to retain more water. Use your head here, they‚Äôre talking about reforesting where there was already forests before humans destroyed it, if it wasn‚Äôt a desert there before with those extra trees there, why would it be any worse replanting them where they already were? You know what happens to land when there‚Äôs no forest/vegetation? It turns into a desert. They‚Äôre called rainforests because they make rain, without the trees the area would revert to a dry plain or a desert.
author: Gorindakia

text: ¬†@Ionor Rea's Spam Generator¬† planting trees will cause more rain and more importantly more stable rainfall, less huge storms, less dry times, I don‚Äôt see how planting a forest on unused former forest would affect anyone‚Äôs way of life besides providing a place to go camping, hiking, biking, walking dogs, 4 wheeling or dirt biking and trees slow wind speeds and even out temperatures so the likely hood of tornadoes should go down. I don‚Äôt know if anyone‚Äôs run simulations but if the area was a forest beforehand there‚Äôs millions of years of ‚Äúsimulation‚Äù backing it. As far as sudden changes, yes they‚Äôre bad for a habitat like if you clear cut a forest in a few months but replanting will take decades for the trees to grow up, there shouldn‚Äôt be any negative repercussions from that and besides even if you somehow plunked thousands of new fully grown trees to a habitat in a day what‚Äôs the worse that could happen? It‚Äôs providing shelter and food for animals so populations would pretty quickly rise again until equilibrium is reached. Some non forest dwelling creatures may be affected but they shouldn‚Äôt have been there anyways, it was a forest beforehand.
author: Gorindakia

text: ¬†@Mike D¬† you‚Äôre almost right about water evaporating from the ocean, yes all the water inland initially at some point came from the ocean but that‚Äôs many cycles later, water doesn‚Äôt make it very far each time it‚Äôs evaporated, before plants evolved, coasts would get a lot of rainfall but inland pretty much everywhere would be very dry. You know what helped move moisture inland? Trees, they soak up what water has rained in the environment and retranspire it again so it can move again further inland, once that happens more trees can grow there and start evapotranspiring that water and allowing it to move even further inland. Yes all water initially comes from the ocean but it can only do it with the help of trees.
author: Gorindakia

text: ¬†@Mike D¬† as far as trees not helping soil moisture, why don‚Äôt you find somewhere near you with a forest close to a grassy field. Bring a shovel with you and go dig a foot deep in the earth in the forest and do the same in the field, come back and tell me which was wetter. Or better yet, go out into your yard with a shovel, dig a foot deep on a patch of baron earth, no plants just dirt, do it again in the grass and one more time in the shadow under a tree. What you‚Äôll find is the bare earth will be the wettest then the grass then the area under the tree. You keep being almost right but you miss the mark to fit your narrative. Climate scientists don‚Äôt have a narrative, they‚Äôre trying to fix the planet. Climate change deniers have a narrative because they want to avoid the truth and destroy the planet to keep milking money out of the fossil fuel industry and avoid change in their lives. It‚Äôs time to grow up and do the responsible thing. Renewables will create more jobs than fossil fuels ever did and are getting cheaper and cheaper. If we stopped subsidizing the fossil fuel industry and started giving that funding to renewables that would be a great step to fixing things, at no extra cost to taxpayers.

text:
¬†@Gorindakia¬† This guy sure said a lot without having any idea what he is talking about. Trees don't make rain and the rainforest isn't called a rainforest because it creates rain. Terrain creates the climate. Mountains ring the moisture out of the air and one side is wet the other side is desert. No amount of tree will change that. 

Look at the US great plains. The areas just east of the Rocky Mountains are dry deserts. A bit further east let's say Minnesota is thousands of miles from the ocean with very little trees between it and the gulf of mexico which is it's source of moisture, yet it is lush and green with substantial yearly rainfall. Not because trees carry moisture from 2500 miles south but because there are no mountains between them so the trade winds can easily carry the moisture.

The trees grow because there is rain, the trees don't grow to create the rain.
